chapter.title: Remote Installation
chapter.para: &productnamereg; can be installed in different ways. In addition to the usual media installation covered in , you can choose from various network-based approaches or even opt for an unattended installation of &productname;.
provides outlines for the different possible procedures. The following sections explain how to use the provided methods to remotely connect to the installation.

sect1.title: Installation Scenarios for Remote Installation
sect1.para: This section introduces the most common installation scenarios for remote installations. For each scenario, carefully check the list of prerequisites and follow the procedure outlined for that scenario. If in need of detailed instructions for a particular step, follow the links provided for each one of them.

sect2.title: Simple Remote Installation via VNC—Static Network Configuration
sect2.para: This type of installation still requires some degree of physical access to the target system to boot for installation. The installation is controlled by a remote workstation using VNC to connect to the installation program. User interaction is required as with the manual installation in .
For this type of installation, make sure that the following requirements are met:

listitem.para: A repository, either remote or local:
Remote repository: NFS, HTTP, FTP, TFTP, or SMB with working network connection.
Local repository, for example a DVD.
Target system with working network connection.
Controlling system with working network connection and VNC viewer software.
Physical boot medium (CD, DVD, or flash disk) for booting the target system.
Valid static IP addresses already assigned to the repository and the controlling system.
Valid static IP address to assign to the target system.

procedure.para: To perform this kind of installation, proceed as follows:

step.para: Set up the installation target and installation server as described in .
Boot the target system using DVD1 of the &productname; media kit.
When the boot screen of the target system appears, use the boot options prompt to set the appropriate VNC options and the address of the repository. Example:
step.screen: install=(nfs,http,ftp,smb)://PATH_TO_INSTMEDIA netdevice=NETDEVICE hostip=IP_ADDRESS netmask=NETMASK gateway=IP_GATEWAY vnc=1 VNCPassword=PASSWORD
step.para: The target system boots to a text-based environment, giving the network address and display number under which the graphical installation environment can be addressed by any VNC viewer application or browser. VNC installations announce themselves over OpenSLP and if the firewall settings permit. They can be found using slptool as described in .
On the controlling workstation, open a VNC viewing application or Web browser and connect to the target system as described in .
Perform the installation as described in . Reconnect to the target system after it reboots for the final part of the installation.
Finish the installation.

sect2.title: Remote Installation via VNC—PXE Boot and Wake on LAN
sect2.para: This type of installation is completely hands-off. The target machine is started and booted remotely. User interaction is only needed for the actual installation. This approach is suitable for cross-site deployments.
To perform this type of installation, make sure that the following requirements are met:

listitem.para: Remote repository: NFS, HTTP, FTP, or SMB with working network connection.
TFTP server.
Running DHCP server for your network.
Target system capable of PXE boot, networking, and Wake on LAN, plugged in and connected to the network.
Controlling system with working network connection and VNC viewer software.

procedure.para: To perform this type of installation, proceed as follows:

step.para: Set up the installation target and installation server as described in .
Set up a TFTP server to hold a boot image that can be pulled by the target system. This is described in .
Set up a DHCP server to provide IP addresses to all machines and reveal the location of the TFTP server to the target system. This is described in .
Prepare the target system for PXE boot. This is described in further detail in .
Initiate the boot process of the target system using Wake on LAN. This is described in .
On the controlling workstation, open a VNC viewing application or Web browser and connect to the target system as described in .
Perform the installation as described in . Reconnect to the target system after it reboots for the final part of the installation.
Finish the installation.

sect2.title: Simple Remote Installation via SSH—Static Network Configuration
sect2.para: This type of installation still requires some degree of physical access to the target system to boot for installation and to determine the IP address of the installation target. The installation itself is entirely controlled from a remote workstation using SSH to connect to the installer. User interaction is required as with the regular installation described in .
For this type of installation, make sure that the following requirements are met:

listitem.para: Remote repository: NFS, HTTP, FTP, or SMB with working network connection.
Target system with working network connection.
Controlling system with working network connection and working SSH client software.
Boot the target system using DVD1 of the &productname; media kit.
Valid static IP addresses already assigned to the repository and the controlling system.
Valid static IP address to assign to the target system.

procedure.para: To perform this kind of installation, proceed as follows:

step.para: Set up the installation target and installation server as described in .
Boot the target system using DVD1 of the &productname; media kit.
When the boot screen of the target system appears, use the boot options prompt to set the appropriate parameters for network connection, address of the repository, and SSH enablement. Example:
step.screen: install=(nfs,http,ftp,smb)://PATH_TO_INSTMEDIA netdevice=NETDEVICE hostip=IP_ADDRESS netmask=NETMASK gateway=IP_GATEWAY ssh=1 ssh.password=PASSWORD
step.para: The target system boots to a text-based environment, giving the network address under which the graphical installation environment can be addressed by any SSH client.
On the controlling workstation, open a terminal window and connect to the target system as described in .
Perform the installation as described in . Reconnect to the target system after it reboots for the final part of the installation.
Finish the installation.

note.title: Avoid Lost Connections After the Second Step (Installation)
note.para: In the network settings dialog, check the Traditional Method with ifup and avoid &nm;. If not, your SSH connection will be lost during installation. Reset the settings to User Controlled with &nm; after your installation has finished.

sect1.title: Monitoring Installation via VNC
sect1.para: Using any VNC viewer software, you can remotely control the installation of &productname; from virtually any operating system. This section introduces the setup using a VNC viewer application or a Web browser.

sect2.title: Preparing for VNC Installation
sect2.para: To enable VNC on the installation target, specify the appropriate boot options at the initial boot for installation (see ). The target system boots into a text-based environment and waits for a VNC client to connect to the installation program.

The installation program announces the IP address and display number needed to connect for installation. If you have physical access to the target system, this information is provided right after the system booted for installation. Enter this data when your VNC client software prompts for it and provide your VNC password.

Because the installation target announces itself via OpenSLP, you can retrieve the address information of the installation target via an SLP browser without the need for any physical contact to the installation itself, provided your network setup and all machines support OpenSLP:

step.para: Run slptool findsrvtypes | grep vnc to get a list of all services offering VNC. The VNC installation targets should be available under a service named YaST.installation.suse.
Run slptool findsrvs YaST.installation.suse to get a list of installations available. Use the IP address and the port (usually 5901) provided with your VNC viewer.

sect2.title: Connecting to the Installation Program
sect2.para: To connect to a VNC server (the installation target in this case), start an independent VNC viewer application on any operating system.
Using VNC, you can control the installation of a Linux system from any other operating system, including other Linux flavors, Windows, or macOS.
On a Linux machine, make sure that the package tightvnc is installed. On a Windows machine, install the Windows port of this application, which can be obtained at the TightVNC home page ().

sect1.title: Monitoring Installation via SSH
sect1.para: Using SSH, you can remotely control the installation of your Linux machine using any SSH client software.

sect2.title: Preparing for SSH Installation
sect2.para: In addition to installing the required software package (OpenSSH for Linux and PuTTY for Windows), you need to specify the appropriate boot options to enable SSH for installation. See for details. OpenSSH is installed by default on any &suselinux;–based operating system.

step.para: Retrieve the installation target's IP address. If you have physical access to the target machine, take the IP address the installation routine provides in the console after the initial boot. Otherwise take the IP address that has been assigned to this particular host in the DHCP server configuration.
In a command line, enter the following command:
Replace TARGET_IP_ADDRESS with the actual IP address of the installation target.
When prompted for a user name, enter root.
When prompted for the password, enter the password that has been set with the SSH boot option. After you have successfully authenticated, a command line prompt for the installation target appears.
Enter yast to launch the installation program. A window opens showing the normal &yast; screens as described in .

sect1.title: Monitoring Installation via Serial Console
sect1.para: For this installation method, you need a second computer connected by a null modem cable to the computer on which to install &productname;. Hardware and firmware of both machines need to support the serial console. Some firmware implementations are already configured to send the boot console output to a serial console (by providing a device tree with /chosen/stdout-path set appropriately). In this case no additional configuration is required.

If the firmware is not set up to use the serial console for the boot console output, you need to provide the following boot parameter at the boot prompt of the installation system (see for details): console=TTY,BAUDRATE

BAUDRATE needs to be replaced by the baud rate for the interface. Valid values are 115200, 38400, or 9600. TTY needs to be replaced by the name of the interface. On most computers, there is one or more serial interfaces. Depending on the hardware, the names of the interfaces may vary:

listitem.para: ttyS0 for APM
ttyAMA0 for Server Base System Architecture (SBSA)
ttyPS0 for Xilinx
